message_1: In a 4-player centipede game, Player 1 has 10 points and Player 2 has 15 points. The game ends if a player decides to take the points or if the last round is reached. Each round adds 2 points to the pot. If a player takes the pot, they get to keep the points and the game ends. If a player passes on taking the pot, the next player has the opportunity to take it or pass. If no one takes the pot, the game ends after 10 rounds. What is the optimal strategy for Player 1 to maximize their expected points?
message_2:
In a centipede game, the optimal strategy is to work backwards from the last round. Let's analyze the game round by round, starting from the last round (round 10).

Round 10:
The pot has 20 points (10 initial rounds * 2 points per round). Player 4 has the last chance to take the pot or pass. Since taking the pot gives them 20 points, which is better than passing and getting 0 points, Player 4 will always take the pot.

Round 9:
The pot has 18 points. Player 3 knows that Player 4 will take the pot in the next round, so they should take the pot now to get 18 points instead of passing and getting 0 points.

Round 8:
The pot has 16 points. Player 2 knows that Player 3 will take the pot in the next round, so they should take the pot now to get 16 points instead of passing and getting 15 points.

Round 7:
The pot has 14 points. Player 1 knows that Player 2 will take the pot in the next round, so they should take the pot now to get 14 points instead of passing and getting 10 points.

So, the optimal strategy for Player 1 is to take the pot in round 7, which will maximize their expected points to 14.
